text:
Okay Uruk's lets all not stab the horse in the face, literally the easiest thing to do just one gash in the leading horse and the rest of them will topple over- OH MY GOD THEIR HORSES ARE FUCKING LAUNCHED US, NOR WILL ANYBODY EVEN COME CLOSE TO STABBING THEIR HORSES!

Okay Uruk's, place your spears in a big massive spear wall, horses can't get past that. They'll just get stabbed to death, or if the horse isn't dumb and actually wants to live, will just stop moving and since that hill seems very steep, probably tip over and then it'll be a domino effect- OH BRIGHT LIGHT, LET THEM THROUGH PULL YOUR SPEARS UP AND IF YOUR SPEAR IS STILL DOWN THE HORSES WON'T HIT THEM ANYWAYS!

I like movie logic, I especially like it how logically I think of everything. I can't just suspend my disbelief for anything anymore.﻿

text:
So many brave uruk-hai and orcs fought for the upcoming morning of their race, in a world they would not to have the racism and arrogance of the elves, the hate of the men and the greediness of the dwarfs...

The memory of the brave have been shadowed by the evilness of the historians... claiming that they had overpowered their enemies and they would have been evil...
Mordor was pinned between great powers of Rohan and Gondor, the whole world was against them...
They were surrounded by enemies...
Isengard was just one fortress surrounded by the great enemies...
Orcs have always lost their wars, against superior enemies, 
dying by great numbers while defending the honor of Melkor and Sauron,
they gave everything they had for their people and friends..
everything...
All I can say... Orcish heroes, rest well, rest brave in your graves, you, the heroes of Isengard and Mordor...﻿
author: Karthago On Tuhottava

text:
An Orc-pacifist?! What are you doing here in this part of Middle-earth? I should cut off your tongue for those false lies, and blind you with tongs so hot that it would melt stone! 
And do you not know of the Orcs hiding in the deeps of Hithaeglir, the Mountains of Mist? Ha! Fool, walk amongst them, and see if they will not slit your throat, or take you to their hidden chambers were you shall be defiled and tortured!

And what nonsense! The East and South were under the domination of the Abhorred, do not twist fact! And what great enemies that you speak of? Gondor, my home, or the Horselords in the North? 
Angrenost was never surrounded, ally of Orcs, their allies lay with the Hill-men of the Enedwaith, west of them, what stupidity!
The Orcs have wittled us down to nothing but ashes, they destroyed our homes, slaughtered our people, and defiled the land; why can we not do the same to them? The wrongs they have done upon us are many, much more than what we have done upon them!

I was at the Pelennor. I saw the horrors these 'heroes' have done. They flung the heads of their captives, good men of Gondor, into the White City. Tell me, Orc-friend, what hero will have done that? Fiend, tell me. Why will these 'heroes' do something so barbaric? 

I will return with my friends, old soldiers of Gondor, and with sword and axe we shall purge you of this world!﻿
author: Fat Russian Faggot

text: +Minalcar Calmacilion Anárioni After all you have done to them, all they did was some psychological warfare. Orcs gave everything for their nation. You can't justify your crimes by the other races.﻿
author: Karthago On Tuhottava

text:
+Karthago On Tuhottava Child, do you know what happens to a captive when he or she is captured by Orcs? I have seen the aftermath of their work, and to say that none dared to bury the bodies is an understatement, a display of their cruelty and madness. 
Tell me, child. Have you fought upon Pelennor? Have you fought upon the earth of Mordor? No? You have not seen what Orcs are capable of. They are masters of torture and delight in destruction.
And what nation? The Orcs do not have a realm! I knew that you were no servant of the Abhorred. Why? Because no emissary of Mordor would speak so highly of Orcs. 
You were born in the time after the War.
 I fought in the War, and I had lost my left hand to an Orc-axe during that day upon Pelennor. 
And what we did to them was justified; the Orcs always swung the first stroke, never us. And I would quote one loremaster of the Archives, 'for every action there must be an equal and opposite reaction' we did what we had to.
Alas! They carry out the will of their masters, what hero is one who cannot even break free from the bondage of their masters? 
And the Orcs have done more wrongs to all the Free Peoples than there are Orcs themselves. 
They are no heroes, they are savages that we should have no contact with. You are a delusional Orc-pacifist. Careful where you speak these words, else you will have a blade upon your throat held by a veteran of the War.﻿
author: Fat Russian Faggot

text: +Minalcar Calmacilion Anárioni I would fight for the all-seeing-eye before, now and in the future. Careful, gondorian, or you will lose your right hand too.﻿
author: Karthago On Tuhottava

text: +Karthago On Tuhottava Try! I slew seventeen Uruks on my lonesome, slew six of your bastard kin of Harad, and slew a Half-troll! And together with three other of my brothers, the Swan Knights of Dol Amroth, we, all at once, thrust our lances into an Olog-hai's thick hide, and we ended him rightly, all this at the Battle of the Pelennor! What hope do you have? None! Go back to the shadow under the mountains and live out your days in fear of the wrath of Gondor!﻿

author: Karthago On Tuhottava

text:
+Karthago On Tuhottava Haha, thirty thousand Orcs? That is only a Tuesday for us men of Gondor! Indeed, I may be one man, but each man of Gondor, let alone a veteran knight of Dol Amroth, is worth thirty Orcs and two Trolls! What can your South-people do that can at the least, contend with our children? Slay a rat?
Gondor has faced twenty to one odds, and came out as the victor in more than battles than we have lost. 
Pray tell, how do you expect for such wretched creatures as the Orcs to conquer Ambar? 
They hide in their cave-cities, and skulk and die and slay each other, how can they hope to conquer such vast lands? 
They cannot overcome the might of Gondor or Rohan, let alone the entirety of Ambar.
You are an idiot. Shame that our ancestors, the Númenóreans, wiped off your scum from the face of the earth, as they did with hundreds of thousands of others who dared to contend with glorious Númenor!﻿

author: Nick Kenniston

text: This scene isn't about the dodgy military tactics. This is about Western men in the eleventh hour rising up against the impossible; making one last charge to defend their civilization. I mean "West" in the literal sense, of course, although the Western men in the story also do a fantastic job. This captures the spirit of the defenders of Vienna in 1683, although it could also stand in for any battle where civilized men fought to the end against an overwhelming enemy, such as at Tours, Thermopylae, Salamis, or the Battle of Britain.﻿

author: TJader De Alba

text:
+TJader De Alba A great horn blows. The orcs to the outside of the formation stop and turn towards the sound. Above them on the ridge, silhouetted against the sky is a white rider, and behind him comes men in great numbers. They flow around the rider and lock shields.

step

The wall advances.

step

A song begins, a song of death, of acceptance of death, of the desire for death. It swells from a thousand throats, rising over the noise of the battlefield.

step

There are archers on the ridge, great bows of yew in their hands, their wild blond hair streaming in the wind.

step

All is silent, though the men still sing and the orcs turn their flank to meet the attack.

step

The archers draw their bows and loose. For one precious moment the arrows hang in the air, then plummet to the ground, killing and wounding orcs all along the front lines.

step

Sound has returned to the world and the shield wall picks up pace as the song draws to a close. Arrows rain down upon the orcs, a glittering hailstorm.

step

The white rider raises his arm and the orcs are blinded by a sudden flash of light. The last volley has been spent, the shield wall charges towards the orcs at maximum speed. 

There is a loud crash of splintering wood as the two sides come together. Like shafts are shattered, shields are splintered. Men die, orcs die, but the men are inside the reach of the pikes, stabbing, hacking, cutting the orcs to pieces.

The orcs break. They flee to the only refugee they can see, the ominous forest that was not there the evening before. The battle is won.﻿

author: Anthony

text:
Yup!

There suddenly upon a ridge appeared a rider, clad in white, shining in the rising sun. Over the low hills the horns
were sounding. Behind him, hastening down the long slopes, were a thousand men on foot; their swords were in their hands.
Amid them strode a man tall and strong. His shield was red. As he came to the valley’s brink, he set to his lips a
great black horn and blew a ringing blast.

‘Erkenbrand!’ the Riders shouted. ‘Erkenbrand!’
‘Behold the White Rider!’ cried Aragorn. ‘Gandalf is come again!’
‘Mithrandir, Mithrandir!’ said Legolas. ‘This is wizardry indeed! Come! I would look on this forest, ere the spell changes.’
The hosts of Isengard roared, swaying this way and that, turning from fear to fear. Again the horn sounded from the tower.
Down through the breach of the Dike charged the king’s company. Down from the hills leaped Erkenbrand, lord of Westfold.
Down leaped Shadowfax, like a deer that runs surefooted in the mountains.
The White Rider was upon them, and the terror of his coming filled the enemy with madness.
The wild men fell on their faces before him. The Orcs reeled and screamed and cast aside both sword and spear.
Like a black smoke driven by a mounting wind they fled. Wailing they passed under the waiting shadow of the
trees; and from that shadow none ever came again.﻿

text:
+Sarah Callaghan The orcs were panicking before they got hit, however the point remains that the attack while it is on horseback is supposed to be on foot, and the result should be pictured from the outcome which would come from a foot charge, essentially the horses are only cosmetic.

Please do not describe the Hussars as some videogame unit, with stats.
The hussars were simply heavy cavalry, deployed properly and therefore effective.
There is nothing that makes them stand up from other heavy cavalry, like the Free-knights/reiters of Germany or the Chevaliers from France conquistadors from Spain or the Mongolian cavalry.

It is how they were deployed, they were not inherently better than other cavalry. ﻿

author: Tripp Fields

text: Everyone is looking way to into the logic surrounding the Uruk pike formation. First off, this is in a world where Trolls, Wizards, Dwarfs, Elves, Giant Eagles, Fell-Beasts, Orcs/Uruk-Hai, exist. Gandalf was leading the charge, a Maiar Wizard destined to guide the Men of the West to a time of peace and prosperity. His light blinded the Uruks who had zero chance when they were crippled against the Rohirrim aka the most lethal horse-men in all of a fantasy world that at being Middle Earth. Therefore, my point is, just enjoy the beauty of these films. Questioning the realism of a charge that takes place in a fictional land seems silly. If this were real or striving for complete realism, yes, the Rohirrim would've been slaughtered. But, plain and simple, it's a fantasy.﻿

author: Khlifa Abdou

text: The Uruk-Hai are superb heavy infantry. Big, mean, and resilient. That scene in Two Towers where they've been on the run from Aragorn, Legolas, and Gimli, they move at a full sprint in heavy iron plate all day for several days straight and show they have inhuman endurance and stamina. Not to mention they reacted with admirable military precision to the appearance of Gandalf and the Rohirrim, realigning their flank and forming pike lines without hesitation. If only they had held out in the face of the blinding sun (a dubious prospect, but one that has been addressed more than enough already), that heroic charge would have been broken like a driftwood raft on rocks. And even blind, if they simply held the pikes before them and shut their eyes, the overlapping layers would still have caught the horses. I kind of want to see a movie where the bad guys win because they have the strength and resources to do so. The closest thing to that would be the Hoth scene from Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back, but then its no fun if the good guys don't overcome impossible odds.﻿

author: JoeySkate24

text:
I think alot of people complain about the horses charging pikes, but the problem runs far deeper. Peter Jackson simply does not know how to make fighting scenes. I mean, he clearly masters tension, surprises and the whole cinema tricks, but does not know the basics of combat. The orcs run around with heavy armour that's just there for decoration. They would be immune to most blows, and would have been a terrible fighting force. Instead of this, we get orcs that ragdoll by merely touching a horse or sword. The orcs are also goddamn retarded for such a trained fighting force. They do absolutely nothing with their pikes. And if they could actually use their pikes, they suddenly don't have any.

I love the movies, but people should stop defending the fighting scenes so hard, trying to use any little argument and stretch it too much, and just admit that the fighting is junk.﻿

Yeah, that simply illuminates the large pile of dead horses and mutilated riders.

A spear-wall formation wouldn't be massively changed by some sun in their eyes, all they need to do it continue pointing their spears forward and let the horses charge into them.

The only advantage the Rohirrim have in this situation is pure momentum, they can push through the spears a bit and hope to charge over their dead front few lines, but almost all of the Uruk hai are seen to be using spears of some sort.

Basically, charging horses into dense, heavily armored, spear wielding infantry would be akin to ordering your cavalry to charge into the mouth of an erupting volcano in order to plug it...

Just pointing out a silly feature.﻿

He also drops in fictional words and terms so casually its almost like reading Shakespeare, where you have to re-read a sentence just to re-grasp the context. The battles and such are much more interesting though, for example, the battle of the Pellannor fields. Aragorn didn't arrive with the army of the dead for the clean sweep victory, he arrived with rangers from the north and armies from Gondorian territories that were under siege by corsairs.﻿

Fair enough, I study music but that isn't to say I should dictate peoples tastes, I just like to give my opinion on things.﻿
author: Anglo Varangoi

text: +kar12894 Actually if you want to get technical it goes back to Richard Wagner. He was one of the pioneers of the concept of letting the actors and dialogue present the reality aspects, and then the music presents the deeper emotional and symbolic aspects that you can't always get from the action on stage or screen. Not all score composers use this method and it depends on the situation, but it's definitely fitting for Lord of the Rings. ﻿
